TextView.android:text: 1 Alphabet Review In Lessons 1 through 4 you studied 20 shorthand strokes. See how fast you can read them.
2 A, A The large circle that represents the long sound of a, as in main. also represents the vowel sounds heard in as and arm.

3 E, I, Obscure Vowel The tiny circle that represents the sound of e, as in heat, also represents the vowel sounds heard in let, him, and the obscure vowel sound (called "schwa" in some dictionaries) in her, hurt.
4 Th Two tiny curves, written upward, are provided for the sounds of th. These curves are called "ith."
At this time you need not try to decide which th stroke to use in a word; this will become clear to you as your study of Gregg Shorthand progresses.
5 Brief Forms Here is another group of brief forms for frequently used words. You will be wise to learn them well.
6 Common Phrases Here are some useful phrases employing these brief forms.
